title: What to Know About Vitamin D and COVID-19
author: Shishira Sreenivas

content: Vitamin D is an important nutrient your body needs to build and keep your bones strong, among other benefits. Sunlight is the main source -- your skin absorbs the sun’s ultraviolet rays and turns them into vitamin D.

But many people are deficient, or don’t get enough. This is especially true if you’re older, don’t eat healthy foods, or have a darker skin tone. And those low levels may raise your risk of severe COVID-19 if infected. Here’s what you need to know.

content_blocks.text: Vitamin D is an important nutrient your body needs to build and keep your bones strong, among other benefits. Sunlight is the main source -- your skin absorbs the sun’s ultraviolet rays and turns them into vitamin D.

But many people are deficient, or don’t get enough. This is especially true if you’re older, don’t eat healthy foods, or have a darker skin tone. And those low levels may raise your risk of severe COVID-19 if infected. Here’s what you need to know.

sections.heading: Vitamin D and COVID-19
content: While vitamin D boosts your immune system and eases inflammation , experts say more research is needed on its antiviral properties.
Several studies indicate that those with low vitamin D levels are at increased risk of SARS-CoV-2 infection and have worse clinical outcomes after infection.

And while high levels of vitamin D might lower your risk for severe COVID infection, there's no evidence that taking vitamin D supplements will provide protection against infection or improve outcomes in patients with COVID.

content_blocks.text: While vitamin D boosts your immune system and eases inflammation , experts say more research is needed on its antiviral properties.
Several studies indicate that those with low vitamin D levels are at increased risk of SARS-CoV-2 infection and have worse clinical outcomes after infection.

And while high levels of vitamin D might lower your risk for severe COVID infection, there's no evidence that taking vitamin D supplements will provide protection against infection or improve outcomes in patients with COVID.

sections.heading: Vitamin D and Other Conditions
content: Not getting enough vitamin D may lead to or worsen these health problems:
All these can raise your risk for severe COVID if infected.
Research shows that obesity and diabetes are linked to low levels of vitamin D. They’re also associated with higher death rates or severe COVID symptoms.
bullets: Infections and issues with your immune system
Certain types of cancer like colon , prostate , and breast cancers

Research shows that obesity and diabetes are linked to low levels of vitamin D. They’re also associated with higher death rates or severe COVID symptoms.

sections.heading: How to Get More Vitamin D
content: More sunlight and foods rich in vitamin D are the best ways. Try to get 15-20 minutes of sunlight, three days a week. And eat foods like:
Supplements are also an option. Ask your doctor how much vitamin D you need before taking them. If you overdo it, you may have symptoms like:
bullets: Ataxia , a neurological condition that causes you to slur or stumble

sources: Medscape: “High Vitamin D Levels May Not Protect Against COVID-19.”
University of Chicago Medicine: “Study suggests high vitamin D levels may protect against COVID-19, especially for Black people.”
JAMA Network: “Association of Vitamin D Levels, Race/Ethnicity, and Clinical Characteristics With COVID-19 Test Results.”
Journal of the American Medical Association : “Effect of a Single High Dose of Vitamin D3 on Hospital Length of Stay in Patients With Moderate to Severe COVID-19: A Randomized Clinical Trial.”
Clinical Medicine Journal: “Does vitamin D deficiency increase the severity of COVID-19?”
Cleveland Clinic: “Vitamin D Deficiency,” “42% Percent of Americans Are Vitamin D Deficient. Are You Among Them?”
PLOS Medicine : “Vitamin D and COVID-19 susceptibility and severity in the COVID-19 Host Genetics Initiative: A Mendelian randomization study.”
Harvard Health: “Do vitamin D, zinc, and other supplements help prevent COVID-19 or hasten healing?”
Mayo Clinic: “Can vitamin D protect against the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19)?”
Biomolecules : “Emerging Role of Vitamin D and its Associated Molecules in Pathways Related to Pathogenesis of Thrombosis.”
meta_description: WebMD explores what the research says about vitamin D and COVID-19.
